text: Heijō-kyō (, also known as Heizei-kyō) was twice the ancient Imperial capital of Japan from 710 to 784. It was where Nara is today.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2002). "Heijō-kyō" in Japan Encyclopedia, pp. 304-305. ==History== In 710, Empress Gemmei moved the Imperial capital from Fujiwara-kyō which is about 18 km south. ===Timeline=== * 707 (Keiun 4): Emperor Mommu orders construction of a new capital city, but the work is not complete before his death.Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du Japon, p. 64. * 710 (Wadō 3, 3rd month): Empress Gemmei moves from Fujiwara-kyō to Heijō-kyō. The palace of the empress was named Nara-no-miya.Brown, Delmer. (1979). Gukanshō, p. 270. * 784 (Enryaku 3): Capital is moved briefly to Nagaoka * 794 (Enryaku 13): Capital was moved to Heian-kyō and the palace was named Heian no Miya.Brown, p. 277. * November 17, 794 (Enryaku 13, 21st day of the 10th month): The emperor traveled by carriage from Nara to Heian-kyō in a grand procession.Brown, p. 279. This marks the end of the Nara period and the beginning of the Heian period in Japanese history. ==Architecture== The Heijō PalaceNaracity Tourist Association, World Heritage ; retrieved 2011-12-8. and some of the Buddhist temples at Heijō-kyō are named together as a UNESCO World Heritage Site,UNESCO, "Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara"; retrieved 2012-4-19. including * Daian-ji (大安寺) * Yakushi-ji (薬師寺) * Kōfuku-ji (興福寺) * Gangō-ji (元興寺) * Suzakumon (朱雀門, reconstruction) * Saidai-ji (西大寺) * Tōdai-ji (東大寺) * Daikokuden (大極殿, reconstruction) ==Related pages == * List of World Heritage Sites in Japan * Capital of Japan ==References== ==Other websites== * Jô-Bô System of Heijô-Kyô * Nara (Heijô-kyô) — The Capital of Japan in the 8th Century Category:Former capitals of Japan Category:8th century in Japan
